nodes.text: Counties causally affect children's adult incomes; estimating county-level causal exposure effects identifies which places produce better intergenerational mobility

Method: estimate county (and commuting-zone) causal exposure effects using a fixed‑effects mover design that regresses children's age-26 income ranks on county fixed effects interacted with fraction of childhood spent in each county, including origin-by-destination fixed effects and cohort/parent-rank controls

Identification assumption: conditional on origin-by-destination fixed effects and observed controls, timing of moves (child age at move) is orthogonal to other determinants of children's potential outcomes for each county

Validation: tests include (a) controlling for pre/post-move parental income and marital status, (b) placebo tests using teenage labor force participation (age 16) and movers after exposure window (moves after child age 23); these checks provide evidence supporting the orthogonality assumption

Result: magnitude of place effects — for children from low-income (25th percentile) families, one year of childhood exposure to a one standard deviation better county increases adult household income by ~0.5% (equivalently 0.17 percentile points); growing up from birth in a one std‑dev better county implies ~10% higher income by age 26 (approximate, 20 years scaling)

Result: substantial geographic heterogeneity — counties' causal effects vary widely even within metro areas; boys' outcomes vary more across areas than girls', with especially negative effects for boys in highly segregated counties

Method / Forecasting: construct mean-squared-error-minimizing forecasts of county causal effects by optimally shrinking noisy mover fixed-effect estimates toward predictions from permanent residents' outcomes (nonmovers), weighting by precision

Result / Forecasts: shrinkage forecasts improve prediction—examples: DuPage County (IL) forecasted as highest for low-income families (0.80% per year, ~16% from birth), Cook County (Chicago) among lowest (≈ −13% from birth); many opportunity bargains exist (good outcomes without high rents)

Evidence on predictors: correlations between causal effects and area characteristics show that much of the observational associations are driven by causal place effects for group-level features (segregation, income inequality, school test scores, social capital, crime), not just selection

Finding on demographic selection: for individual-level demographic aggregates (fraction single mothers, racial composition, immigrant share) a substantial portion of the correlation with observational mobility statistics is due to sorting/selection, though many such demographics still correlate with causal effects (e.g., black share negatively correlated with county causal effects)

Housing markets and opportunity bargains: within commuting zones rents are only weakly positively correlated with counties' causal effects (rents explain <5% of variance in causal effects for low-income families in many CZs), implying many counties offer above-average child outcomes without substantially higher rents

Explanation candidates for opportunity bargains: (i) disamenities or longer commutes in high-opportunity low-rent places, (ii) limited information about neighborhood causal quality, and (iii) behavioral/frictional constraints that produce suboptimal residential choices for low-income families; evidence suggests information/capitalization plays a substantial role

Conclusion: place-focused policy (helping families move, targeted place-based investments) is promising because county effects are meaningful and partly predictable from observables, but further work is needed to estimate finer-grained geography effects, subgroup heterogeneity, and causal mechanisms before definitive policy prescriptions
